questions.text: Identify X.

A 35-year-old male presents with a foot drop and weakness in the dorsiflexion of the great toe. He mentions a recent history of a herniated lumbar disc. There is decreased sensation over the dorsum of the foot and the first web space between the great toe and the second toe. Which dermatome and root value are most likely involved?

Dermatome

Nerve Supply

Heel (Skin on the heel)

questions.text: Identify the muscle/muscle head that is not included in the hamstring group of muscles.
questions.explanation:
(a) Long head of biceps femoris

(b) Short head of biceps femoris

(c) Semitendinosus

(d) Semimembranosus

 

Semitendinosus

(Option C)

Semimembranosus

(Option D)

Biceps Femoris

Attachments
  • Ischial tuberosity via common tendon with biceps femoris
  • Inserts on the medial surface of the tibia (pes anserinus)
  • Ischial tuberosity (long, flat tendon)
  • Inserts on medial tibial condyle and forms oblique popliteal ligament
  • Long head (Option A): Ischial tuberosity (common tendon with semitendinosus)
  • Short head (Option B): From Linea aspera
  • Inserts on head of fibula

Relations
  • Posterior to semimembranosus
  • Proximally overlaps popliteal vessels
  • Overlaps popliteal vessels
  • Lies deep to semitendinosus
  • Covered by gluteus maximus
  • Lies superficial; deep to it are semimembranosus, sciatic nerve, adductor magnus

Innervation
  • Sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2) through tibial division
  • Sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2) through tibial division
  • Long head: Sciatic nerve (tibial division)
  • Short head: common peroneal part of Sciatic nerve

Actions
  • Flexes knee
  • Extends hip
  • Medial rotation of lower leg
  • Flexes knee
  • Extends hip
  • Medial rotation of lower leg
  • Flexes knee
  • Extends hip
  • Lateral rotation of lower leg

Testing
  • Active knee flexion against resistance
  • Active knee flexion against resistance
  • Active knee flexion against resistance

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is/are supplied by the Nerve to the obturator internus?
questions.correct_answer: B. Gamellus superior and obturator internus
questions.explanation:
Attachments
  • Origin: Pelvic surface of the obturator membrane and surrounding bones
  • Insertion: On the medial surface of the greater trochanter

Vascular Supply
  • Main supply: gemellar branches of the internal pudendal artery
  • Intrapelvic and extrapelvic parts: branches of the obturator artery

Innervation

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2)

Actions

Laterally rotates the extended thigh.

Abducts the flexed thigh.
 

Gemellus Superior
(smaller than G. inferior)

Gamellus Inferior

Attachments
  • Origin: Arises from the dorsal surface of the ischial spine
  • Blends with the upper border of obturator internus tendon
  • Insertion: Medial surface of the greater trochanter.
  • Origin: Arises from the upper part of the ischial tuberosity
  • Blends with the lower border of obturator internus tendon
  • Insertion: Medial surface of the greater trochanter.

Vascular Supply

Supplied by internal pudendal artery, inferior gluteal artery, and sometimes superior gluteal artery

Mainly by the medial circumflex femoral artery

Innervation

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2)

Nerve to quadratus femoris (L4, L5, S1)

Actions
  • Assists obturator internus in lateral rotation of the thigh
  • May assist in abduction of the flexed thigh
  • Rotates the extended thigh laterally
  • May contribute to abduction of the flexed thigh

Attachments
  • Origin: Arises from the ischial tuberosity
  • Insertion: Trochanteric crest of the femur

Vascular Supply

Inferior gluteal artery and medial circumflex femoral artery

Innervation

Nerve to quadratus femoris (L4, L5, S1)

Actions

Produces lateral rotation of the thigh

Gluteus muscle

Innervation

Action

Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

Hip flexor, abductor; stabilizes pelvis; assists in knee extension.

Gluteus maximus

Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)

Hip extension; lateral rotation; assists in stabilizing pelvis

Gluteus medius

Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

Hip abductor; stabilizes pelvis during single-leg stance

Gluteus minimus

Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

Hip abductor; medial rotator of the thigh

Piriformis

Superior gluteal nerve and branches from S1 and S2

Laterally rotates the extended thigh; abducts the flexed thigh

Obturator Internus

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1)

Laterally rotates the extended thigh; abducts the flexed thigh.

Obturator Externus

Posterior branch of the obturator nerve (L3, L4)

Lateral rotation of the thigh; stabilizes hip joint

Gemellus Superior

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2)

Laterally rotates the extended thigh; assists in abduction of the flexed thigh.

Gemellus Inferior

Nerve to quadratus femoris (L4, L5, S1)

Laterally rotates the extended thigh; assists in abduction of the flexed thigh.

Quadratus Femoris

Nerve to quadratus femoris, (L5, S1)

Lateral rotation of the thigh

Quadratus femoris

Quadriceps femoris

Posterior pelvis

Front of the thigh

Nerve to quadratus femoris

Femoral nerve

Produces lateral rotation of the thigh

Extension of knee and flexion of hip

questions.text: Which among the following structures do not pass through both the greater and lesser sciatic foramen?
questions.correct_answer: D. Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
questions.explanation:
Greater sciatic notch/foramen/gateway of gluteal region

Lesser sciatic notch
  • The piriformis, emerging from the pelvis, fills the foramen almost completely. It is the key muscle of the region.
  • Structures passing above the piriformis are:
    • Superior gluteal nerve
    • Superior gluteal vessels
 
  • Structures passing below the piriformis are:
    • Inferior gluteal nerve
    • Inferior gluteal vessels
    • Sciatic nerve
    • The posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh
    • Nerve to quadratus femoris
    • Nerve to obturator internus (Option C)
    • Internal pudendal vessels (Option B)
    • Pudendal nerve (Option A)
  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve (Option A)
  • Internal pudendal vessels (Option B)
  • Nerve to obturator internus (Option C)

The upper and lower parts of the foramen are filled up by the origins of the two gemelli muscles.

questions.text: A 35-year-old athlete presents with difficulty climbing stairs and rising from a seated position. Upon examination, there is weakness in hip extension. Which muscle is most likely affected, and what is the nerve supply?

options.label: A
options.text: Psoas major; Anterior rami of L1, L2, L3

questions.correct_answer: B. Gluteus maximus; Inferior gluteal nerve
questions.explanation:
Action

Muscles

Nerve supply


 

Flexion
  • Psoas major (chief flexor) (Option A)

Anterior rami of L1, L2, L3
  • Iliacus (chief flexor)
  • Sartorius (Option D)
  • Rectus femoris
  • Pectineus

Femoral nerve (L2, L3)
 

Extension
  • Gluteus maximus (chief extensor) (Option B)

Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • Hamstring muscles

Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)
 

Abduction
  • Gluteus medius and minimus (chief abductors)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1) (Option C)


 

Adduction
  • Adductor longus
  • Adductor brevis
  • Adductor magnus (chief adductors)
  • Gracilis

Obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Pectineus

Double nerve supply (Femoral nerve and obturator nerve)
 

Medial rotation
  • Anterior fibres of gluteus minimus and medius (chief medial rotators)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)





 

Lateral rotation
  • Piriformis

Ventral rami of S1, S2
  • Obturator externus

Posterior division of obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Obturator internus and
  • Associated gemelli,
  • Quadratus femoris (These muscles are generally termed short rotators)

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2)

questions.text: In a clinical setting, a physician suspects a weakness in the gluteus maximus muscle. Which of the following functions would not be affected by this?

options.label: C
options.text: Lateral rotation and abduction of the thigh

options.label: D
options.text: Stabilization of pelvis during quiet standing

questions.correct_answer: D. Stabilization of pelvis during quiet standing
questions.explanation:
Features

  • Largest and most superficial in the gluteal region
  • Broad, thick, and quadrilateral
  • Has an overlying adipose fascia
  • Fascicular architecture with large bundles of fibres separated by fibrous septa
 

Origin

  • Gluteal surface of the ilium behind the posterior gluteal line
  • Outer slope of the dorsal segment of ilium
  • Dorsal surfaces of the sacrum and ilium
  • Sacrotuberous ligament
 

Insertions

  • 3/4th of the muscle into the iliotibial tract
  • 1/4th of the muscle into the gluteal tuberosity
 

Vascular Supply
  • Primarily supplied by the inferior gluteal artery (≈ 2/3)
  • Superior gluteal artery
  • Additional supply from the first perforator of profunda femoris and medial circumflex femoral artery
  • Minor branches from lateral circumflex femoral, lateral sacral, and internal pudendal arteries.

Innervation
  • Innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
 

Actions
  • Extends flexed thigh (Option A)
  • Stabilizes pelvis during gait (vs Option D)
  • Active in raising trunk after stooping (Option B)
  • Active in lateral rotation and abduction of the thigh (Option C)
  • Stabilizes femur via iliotibial tract
  • The gluteus maximus is generally inactive during
    • Quiet standing
    • When swaying forward at the ankle joints
    • When bending forward at the hip joints to touch the toes
 

Testing
  • Tested by hip extension against resistance in prone position with knees flexed

He reports that once his knee locks in an extended position, it takes effort to initiate flexion again. On examination, you notice that the patient struggles to begin flexion from full extension. Which muscle is likely impaired?

  • Biceps femoris (Option C)

Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)

Femoral nerve

Unlocking
  • Popliteus (Option B)

Tibial nerve (L4, L5, S1)

Locking

Unlocking

Medial rotation of the femur on the tibia during the terminal phase of extension.

Lateral rotation of the femur on the tibia during the initial phase of the flexion

It is brought about by the quadriceps femoris

It is brought about by the popliteus muscle

Locked knee becomes rigid

Unlocked knee can be further flexed

All ligaments are taut

All ligaments are relaxed

Which of the following does not participate in the cruciate anastomosis?

questions.text: Which of the following regarding the marked structure is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Nerve to obturator internus passes above it

options.label: B
options.text: Innervated by L5, S1 nerve roots

options.label: D
options.text: It is a medial rotator of the hip joint

questions.correct_answer: C. Pudendal nerve passes below it
questions.explanation:
Attachments
  • Origin: Anterior surface of sacrum (3 digitations)
  • Gluteal surface of ilium near posterior inferior iliac spine
  • Capsule of sacroiliac joint
  • Insertion: Medial side of the upper border of the greater trochanter of the femur

The piriformis muscle emerges from the pelvis, almost filling the greater sciatic foramen completely and is the key muscle of the area.

Structures running superior to piriformis
  • Superior gluteal nerve and vessel (Option A)
 

Structures running inferior to piriformis.

  • Inferior gluteal nerve and vessels
  • Greater trochanter
  • Sciatic nerve
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris
  • Nerve to obturator internus
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Pudendal nerve (Option C)
 

Vascular Supply
  • Main supply: Superior gluteal artery
  • Contributions: Gemellar branches of internal pudendal, inferior gluteal artery, lateral sacral artery

Innervation

Innervated by superior gluteal nerve and ventral rami of S1 and S2 (Option B)

Actions
  • Laterally rotates extended thigh (Option D)
  • Abducts flexed thigh
 

Testing
  • No isolated testing; assess for dysfunction by having the seated subject abduct thighs (buttock pain indicates potential involvement)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is being examined for abnormal gait. His Trendelenberg sign is positive. What is false about testing for the Trendelenburg sign?

options.label: A
options.text: The side of the hip that droops down is the unaffected side

options.label: B
options.text: The gluteus medius and minimus muscles are affected

options.label: C
options.text: The patients have a characteristic lurching gait

options.label: D
options.text: The uncompensated Trendelenburg sign is elicited with a walking patient

questions.correct_answer: D. The uncompensated Trendelenburg sign is elicited with a walking patient
questions.explanation:
Tensor Fasciae Latae

Gluteus Medius

Gluteus Minimus

Attachments
  • Origin: Outer lip of the iliac crest extending from the anterior superior iliac spine to the tubercle of the crest.

 

  • Insertion: Iliotibial tract 3–5 cm below the level of the greater trochanter.
  • Origin: Gluteal surface of the ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines
 
  • Insertion: Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
  • Origin: Gluteal surfaces of the ilium between anterior & inferior gluteal lines.
 
  • Insertion: Anterior aspect of the Greater trochanter

Relations
  • Between gluteus medius and sartorius
  • Covered by fascia lata
  • Covered by gluteus maximus (posterior third)
  • Deep to gluteus minimus
  • Deep to gluteus medius
  • Related to hip joint capsule

Vascular Supply
  • Mainly from lateral circumflex femoral artery
  • Supplied by superior gluteal artery
  • Deep branch of superior gluteal artery
  • Trochanteric anastomosis
  • Main trunk and deep branch of superior gluteal artery
  • Trochanteric anastomosis

Innervation
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

Actions
  • Hip flexor and abductor
  • Stabilizes pelvis
  • Helps maintain extended knee
  • Abducts thigh
  • Medial & lateral rotation of thigh
  • Supports pelvis during single-leg stance
  • Abducts thigh
  • Medial and lateral rotation of thigh

Testing
  • Depression below anterior superior iliac spine
  • Abduction against resistance
  • Medial rotation against resistance
  • Abduction against resistance
  • Medial rotation against resistance
  • Abduction against resistance

questions.text: A patient reports pain and decreased sensation along the posterolateral aspect of the lower leg, extending onto the lateral side of the foot, following an ankle sprain. Which nerve is most likely injured?

A 40-year-old man is involved in a car accident and sustains a fracture to the ischial tuberosity. He now presents with weakness in knee flexion and hip extension, with intact sensation. Which muscle group and nerve are likely involved?
Identify the marked structures in the given image:

options.label: A
options.text: a) Semitendinosus, b) Biceps femoris, c) Popliteal artery, d) Tibial nerve

options.label: B
options.text: a) Semitendinosus, b) Biceps femoris, c) Tibial nerve, d) Popliteal artery

options.label: C
options.text: a) Biceps femoris, b) Semitendinosus, c) Popliteal artery, d) Tibial nerve

options.label: D
options.text: a) Biceps femoris, b) Semitendinosus, c) Tibial nerve, d) Popliteal artery

questions.correct_answer: D. a) Biceps femoris, b) Semitendinosus, c) Tibial nerve, d) Popliteal artery
questions.explanation:
Boundaries

  • Superomedial: Semitendinosus and Semimembranosus
  • Superolateral: Biceps Femoris
  • Inferomedial: Medial head of Gastrocnemius
  • Inferolateral: Lateral head of Gastrocnemius and Plantaris
  • Floor (anterior wall): Formed by the popliteal surface of the femur, knee joint capsule, oblique popliteal ligament, and popliteal fascia covering the popliteus muscle.
  • Roof (posterior wall): Formed by the popliteal fascia, containing the short saphenous vein and three cutaneous nerves (posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh, medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh, sural communicating nerve).
    • All structures pierce the roof except the medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh.



 

Contents

Main Contents:

  • Popliteal artery and branches
  • Popliteal vein and tributaries
  • Tibial nerve and branches
  • Common peroneal nerve and branches
  • Popliteal lymph nodes
  • Popliteal fat pad

Additional Structures:

  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh (terminal part)
  • Descending genicular branch of obturator nerve
  • Terminal part of the short saphenous vein

Arrangement of Key Structures (NVA/AVN pattern)
  • Upper part: Nerve, Vein, Artery (lateral to medial)
  • Middle part: Nerve, Vein, Artery (superficial to deep)
  • Lower part: Artery, Vein, Nerve (lateral to medial)

(largest muscle of this compartment)

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with leg pain and weakness after a heavy deadlift. He reports heaviness in his feet, difficulty standing on his toes, and performing calf raises. Neurological examination reveals weakness in plantar flexion, inability to flex his toes and diminished ankle reflexes. Which spinal cord segments are primarily involved in this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Segments

Muscles innervated

L1

Psoas major

L2, L3 (Option C)

Gracilis, pectineus, sartorius

L3, L4 (Option D)

Quadriceps femoris, adductors of the thigh

L4, L5 (Option A)

Tensor fasciae latae, tibialis anterior, tibialis posterior

L5, S1

Gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, peroneus longus, peroneus brevis, semitendinosus, semimembranosus

S1, S2 (Option B)

Gluteus maximus, biceps femoris, gastrocnemius, soleus.

S2, S3

Flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, interossei

Joints

Movements

Hip joint
  • Flexion, adduction, and medial rotation (L2, L3)
  • Extension, abduction, and lateral rotation (L4, L5)

Knee joint
  • Extension (L3, L4)
  • Flexion (L5; S1)

Ankle joint
  • Dorsiflexion (L4, L5)
  • Plantar flexion (S1, S2)

Foot
  • Invertors (L4, L5)
  • Evertors (L5, S1)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a foot drop following a recent knee injury. Which of the following nerves, part of the sacral plexus, is most likely injured, leading to the inability to dorsiflex the foot?
questions.explanation:
Nerve

Formation

Pathway

Functions

Sciatic Nerve

The largest nerve in the body, derived from both anterior and posterior divisions of L4, L5, S1, S2, and S3.

Exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, passing beneath the piriformis muscle, and travels down the posterior thigh.

Supplies the posterior thigh muscles. It divides into two key branches:

  • Tibial Nerve (Anterior Division) (Option B): Innervates the posterior leg and foot muscles.
  • Common Peroneal Nerve (Posterior Division): Innervates muscles of the lateral and anterior leg.

Clinical Note: Injury to the common peroneal nerve can result in foot drop, a condition characterized by difficulty lifting the front part of the foot.

Pudendal Nerve (Option D)

Arises from the anterior divisions of S2, S3, and S4.

Travels out of the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen and into the perineum via the lesser sciatic foramen.

Provides motor and sensory innervation to the perineum, including muscles of the pelvic floor and external genitalia.

  • It is crucial for maintaining continence and sexual function.

Superior Gluteal Nerve

Originates from the posterior divisions of L4, L5, and S1.

Exits the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen, superior to the piriformis muscle.

Innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae, which are responsible for hip abduction and pelvis stabilization during walking.

Inferior Gluteal Nerve

Originates from the posterior divisions of L5, S1, and S2.

Exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, inferior to the piriformis.

Innervates the gluteus maximus, the primary extensor of the hip joint.

Posterior Femoral Cutaneous Nerve (Option A)

Arises from the anterior and posterior divisions of S1, S2, and S3.

Travels alongside the sciatic nerve, exiting the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen.

Provides sensory innervation to the skin on the posterior thigh and lower buttocks.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of tingling and numbness in the outer aspect of his right thigh. He reports that the symptoms worsen when he sits for prolonged periods and improves when he stands or walks. Upon examination, there is a sensory deficit in the lateral thigh region. Which nerve root value is primarily involved in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Nerve

Formation

Pathway

Functions

Obturator Nerve

Formed from the ventral divisions of L2, L3, and L4.

It exits the pelvis through the obturator foramen.

Innervates the muscles of the medial thigh (adductors) and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the medial thigh.

Femoral Nerve

Formed from the dorsal divisions of L2, L3, and L4. (Option C)

It passes under the inguinal ligament into the anterior compartment of the thigh.

Supplies the muscles of the anterior thigh (such as quadriceps) and provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and part of the medial leg.

Lateral Femoral Cutaneous Nerve

Formed from the dorsal divisions of L2 and L3.

It courses laterally across the iliacus muscle and under the inguinal ligament.
  • Provides purely sensory innervation to the skin over the lateral aspect of the thigh.
  • This nerve is particularly important in conditions such as meralgia paresthetica, where it can become compressed, leading to tingling and pain in the outer thigh.
  • Most commonly injured during Mc Roberts manure & Laproscopic hernia surgery.
